thread.title_full: 20 life lessons from the Chicago Cubs - Chicago Tribune

author: Mary Schmich
title: 20 life lessons from the Chicago Cubs - Chicago Tribune
text:
It's been said, many times and many ways, that baseball is like life.
Theo Epstein said it again this week after the New York Mets obliterated the Chicago Cubs in the National League Championship Series.
"It's difficult to reconcile the disappointment of the NLCS with the dream of the season that we had up to that point," Epstein, the Cubs president, said Thursday. "That's baseball and that's life."
Dreams sometimes end in disappointment: That's a lesson that applies far beyond baseball.
In the spirit of baseball-is-like-life, here are a few other life lessons to be extracted from the dearly departed Cubs season.
1. Happiness is a function of expectation.
The higher your expectations, the harder they are to satisfy. No one expected the Cubs to win as many games as they did during the regular season. Their defiance of expectation was part of what made their fans so giddy. It's why even though the ending of the fairy tale was sad, many fans went away happy.
2. Hope is not the same as expectation.
Wrigley Illustrated: After the season ends, the fans remain Nausheen Husain and Rick Tuma As the Cubs and October baseball surprised Chicago, we set out to meet the long-suffering fans and capture the historic time at the friendly confines. We met an 80-year-old woman in Cubs pajamas who holds season tickets and is the only Cubs fan in her entire extended family. Everyone else roots... As the Cubs and October baseball surprised Chicago, we set out to meet the long-suffering fans and capture the historic time at the friendly confines. We met an 80-year-old woman in Cubs pajamas who holds season tickets and is the only Cubs fan in her entire extended family. Everyone else roots... (Nausheen Husain and Rick Tuma) Expectation is a form of demand: This had better happen, or else. Hope is a desire: It would sure be nice if this happened.
Cubs fans hoped the team would make it all the way. Wise fans knew better than to expect it.
3. Surprise is often a key ingredient of pleasure.
Surprise fueled the thrill of the Cubs' season.
4. Surprise, by its nature, never lasts.
Next year — when their success won't be new, when hope has hardened into expectation — the Cubs will have to do even better to supply the same amount of pleasure.
5. A story is more than its ending.
A baseball season is a story. Beginning, middle, end. Characters and dramatic twists. More than anything, the audience wants to be engaged, and by that measure the Cubs gave us a great story.
As Romeo and Juliet could testify, some of the world's best stories don't have happy endings.
6. You can be disappointed that you lost but still glad you played.
If Cubs ever win it all, they would lose their essential nature Bernie Lincicome Not to beat a dead Cub, but …
The Cubs do not need autopsies. Inquests are for serious sins. The Cubs are what they are. No fingers need to be pointed, though a couple of Cubs outfielders might use a few more. I once accused the Cubs of choking, but that was early on and I didn't understand.
I...
Not to beat a dead Cub, but …
The Cubs do not need autopsies. Inquests are for serious sins. The Cubs are what they are. No fingers need to be pointed, though a couple of Cubs outfielders might use a few more. I once accused the Cubs of choking, but that was early on and I didn't understand.
I...
(Bernie Lincicome) Or, to put it the cliche way, it's better to have played and lost than never played at all.
7. Play is good for work.
Or, as Cubs manager Joe Maddon famously put it, "Don't ever permit the pressure to exceed the pleasure." This team had fun, which made them more fun for the rest of us.
8. A good boss makes the workers believe not only in themselves but in each other.
See "Maddon" above.
9. Clothes may not make the man, but a good pair of glasses never hurts.
See "Maddon" above.
10. Work is an investment in success; it doesn't always pay dividends right away.
As Cubs first baseman Anthony Rizzo put it a few days ago, "We set a tone for how we are going to be for a long time."
11. The successful person is sometimes the person whose greatest skill is a good attitude.
In August, the Cubs benched shortstop Starlin Castro, but when the season was over, Epstein praised him:
"Of all the players we can be proud of, he might be the one most deserving of that praise because of everything he went through off the field."
12. You can be brilliant and still not be the best.
Or to put it another way:
13. No matter how good you are there's usually someone better.
The Mets will soon find out.
14. Even the superhuman turn out to be human.
But you were great, Jake Arrieta.
15. Young people can be shockingly good and better than their experienced elders.
The Cubs gave "rookie" a good name.
16. In the face of youthful brilliance, experience may still win.
17. Gracious losers are winners.
The Cubs closed out the season with class, which helped their fans to do the same. Gracious losers, btw, aren't the same as lovable losers.
18. One of the best ways to cure disappointment is to find lessons in it.
See above.
19. Baseball may be like life, but it's not all there is to life.
Seriously, people. Get a grip.
20. There really is always next year.
At least in baseball.
